page.title: 06NATIONAL TRUST NATURE TRAIL
page.content: From Blackdown you can see to the South the chalk South Down, and Chanctonbury Ring. On a clear day you can see the sea. On the Nature trail there are some areas of interest. There are some dew ponds or bog pools. The bog mosses grow in loose tussocks and can take in large amounts of water. In World War I they were collected and used in dressings. A small path, known as Pen Y Bos (an old Celtic name) is an ancient track. Earlier still, Mesolithic Man lived here about 6000 BC. Another place of interest is called the Temple of the Winds, a group of trees at the Southern end of Blackdown much loved by Lord Tennyson. In the 17th Century there was a beacon here, and in the 18th Century a telegraph.
